abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Liuzhou Environment
            Management Project for China were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: like sewerage service, solid waste
            management requires adequate operations and revenues to
            build an effective refuse collection system, and commitment
            from city managers to set up adequate operation policies, in
            particular when landfills are far from the city center, thus
            requiring transfer stations. The Liuzhou Municipal
            Government (LMG) intended to improve the efficiency of its
            solid waste management operations by introducing both
            institutional reforms and cost recovery policies. The
            project provided Technical Assistance (TA) to Liuzhou
            Environmental Sanitation Department (ESD) to analyze various
            institutional options to achieve this objective. Targeting
            multiple cities with complex components can result in
            implementation delays, particularly when project management
            offices (PMOs) and implementing agencies lack staff
            experience in Bank operations. This project involved only
            one city and funded a limited number of high priority
            investments and programs. TA was also provided to the PMO
            and the project implementing agencies to strengthen their
            capacity to implement the project.
